div1.head: Newspaper clipping, The Washington Post, January 17, 1901
div1.p:
We hail with enthusiasm the latest dis-
coveries announced by the “American
commission” in Havana. The estimable
gentlemen who constitute this august body
and who, according to all accounts, have
devoted their energies and brains to the
investigation during the past few months
have now reached a definite conclusion,
which, we are sure, will be received with
real emotion by every yellow fever expert
in the land. A press dispatch, dated Ha-
vana, 9th instant, says:

“The American commission, under the superin-
tendence of Dr. Reed, which has been making ex-
periments at Quemados as to the propagation of the
yellow fever germs by the mosquito, has obtained
extremely satisfactory results.

“Dr. Reed says the experiments show, beyond a
doubt, that there is no contagion from an infected
person or from infected clothing, but that the mos-
quitoes alone are responsible for the spread of the
diesase.”

Dr. Reed and his coadjutors are to be
congratulated upon at least one of their
conclusions, viz., that yellow fever is not
contagious--that is to say, not communi-
cable by one person to another. Although
this has been known to yellow fever spe-
cialists for more than half a century, and
is abundantly proved by the records of the
Charity Hospital, the Parish Prison, and
the Hotel Dieu in New Orleans, it is evi-
dently a brand-new proposition to Dr.
Reed, and he is fully entitled to a patent
on it. No physician has ever filed a ca-
veat in the premises. Dr. Reed bestrides
the field. We know he is right, because
all the great Southern experts--Bruns,
Brickell, Holcombe, Holt, Choppin, and a
hundred others we could name, to say
nothing of the greatest of them all, Dr.
Warren Stone, who went from Connecti-
cut to New Orleans in the forties and soon
revolutionized the treatment of the disease
with magnificent results--we know he is
right because all well-informed people
have certified to it for two generations
past. As far back as 1854 Dr. W. J. Truck,
of Memphis, Tenn., contributed to the
New Orleans Medical and Surgical Journal
an article on yellow fever, in the course
of which he said: “Bearing, then, in mind
the above definition of the term contagion,
as defined by the best authorities and com-
mon usage, we believe the position may be
clearly and fully maintained that yellow
fever is not a contagious disease.” Of
course not. Hundreds of New Orleans
men still living are ready to certify to the
truth of Dr. Reed's pronunciamento. Un-
questionably, he is warranted to this ex-
tent.

As to the mosquitoes--those much-abused
but cheerful and industrious insects--we
are not so sure. The theory offers an easy
escape from a difficulty which has baffled
the profession for many years past. San-
arelli's germs have been exploded. Dr.
Doty, of New York, stands an unveiled
humbug. Every boasted “discovery” of
the yellow fever germ has been repudiated
after scientific and dispassionate investi-
gation. Really, it seems to us that we
might as well put it on the mosquitoes.
They are pests by universal consent, and
they have no friends worth mentioning.

Put it on the mosquitoes and let it go at
that!
